instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the related study to predict the cellulose content in rice stem?
Output: In the related study on predicting the cellulose content in rice stem, the near-infrared(nir) reflectance spectrum was used.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to predict the cellulose content in rice stem?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used to predict the cellulose content in rice stem was Standard Normal Variate (SNV), Continuous Wavelet Transform (CWT), and the combination of the two methods (SNV-CWT).

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the accuracy of the prediction model for cellulose content in rice stems and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the accuracy of the prediction model for cellulose content in rice stems is the coefficient of determination (RP). The coefficient of determination measures the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable (cellulose content) that can be explained by the independent variables (characteristic wavelengths). 

The coefficient of determination (RP) of the test set is reported to be 0.880. This means that approximately 88% of the variance in the cellulose content can be explained by the selected characteristic wavelengths.

instruction: What machine learning models were used to establish prediction models for the near-infrared spectral inversion model of cellulose content in rice stem using hyperspectral technology?
Output: The machine learning models used to establish prediction models for the near-infrared spectral inversion model of cellulose content in rice stem using hyperspectral technology are the support vector machine regression (epsilon-support vector machine regression, epsilon SVR) and the kernel-based extreme learning machine (KELM) prediction model.

instruction: Can the SaDEGWO optimized epsilon SVR model, constructed using the SiPLS-IRIV method and spectral pretreatment with the SNV-CWT method, be used as a superior alternative to traditional methods for predicting cellulose content in rice stems using near-infrared spectral inversion model?
Output: Yes, the SaDEGWO optimized epsilon SVR model, constructed using the SiPLS-IRIV method and spectral pretreatment with the SNV-CWT method, can be used as a superior alternative to traditional methods for predicting cellulose content in rice stems using a near-infrared spectral inversion model. The model has been shown to have the highest accuracy, with a coefficient of determination (RP) of 0.880 and a root-mean-square error (RMSEP) of 15.22 mg.g(-1). This indicates that the model has good predictive ability and can provide a reliable prediction of cellulose content in rice stems.
